On November 21st 2025, thirteen of us travelling with Flamingo Lanka visited the sacred Ruwanweliseya stupa.  This remarkable hemispherical monument, originally constructed in 140 BC by king Dutugemunu, stands as one of the tallest ancient structures in the world at a height of 103 metres, with a circumference of 290 metres and housing and enshrines a large amount of Buddha’s relics within.  Although king Dutugemunu commenced its construction, it was completed after he passed away. The Ruwanweliseya, constructed primarily of brick, is a marvel of ancient engineering.  The sheer volume of bricks required for its construction is staggering.  Its iconic white appearance is maintained by periodic painting of the outer plaster.  It is a living shrine that had been drawing pilgrims and awe-struck visitors for centuries! During our visit there, we joined the many devotees venerating and worshipping the stupa.  As is customary at religious sites, visitors are required to dress modestly and remove their footwear before entry. Ruwanweliseya is open to pilgrims and visitors throughout the day.

The Ruwanweli Maha Seya, also known as the Maha Thupa (lit. 'the Great Thupa'), is a stupa (a hemispherical structure containing relics) in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. Two quarts or one Dona of the Buddha's relics are enshrined in the stupa, making it the largest collection of his relics anywhere.[1] It was built by Sinhalese King Dutugemunu in c. 140 B.C., who became king of Sri Lanka after a war in which the Chola King Elāra (Ellalan) was defeated. It is also known as Swarnamali Seya, Svaṇṇamāli Mahaceti (in Pali) and Rathnamali Seya. Ruwanwelisaya – A Majestic Symbol of Sri Lanka’s Buddhist Heritage Visiting Ruwanwelisaya, one of the most revered and breathtaking stupas in Sri Lanka, was a truly awe-inspiring experience. Located in the sacred city of Anuradhapura, this magnificent white dagoba stands as a testament to the island’s deep Buddhist heritage and architectural brilliance. Historical & Spiritual Significance Built by King Dutugemunu in the 2nd century BCE, Ruwanwelisaya is one of the most important Buddhist monuments in Sri Lanka. It enshrines sacred relics of Lord Buddha and is considered a place of great spiritual power. Pilgrims from across the country visit to pay homage, offering flowers and chanting prayers in deep devotion. Architecture & Ambiance The sheer size and grandeur of Ruwanwelisaya are breathtaking. The towering 103-meter-high stupa with its pristine white dome glows beautifully, especially during sunrise and sunset. The intricate carvings, the famous elephant wall surrounding the stupa, and the peaceful courtyard create a serene and sacred atmosphere. Best Time to Visit Sunrise or Sunset – The soft golden hues create a magical backdrop, making it a perfect time for reflection and photography. Poya Days (Full Moon Days) – Witness thousands of devotees in traditional white attire, engaging in religious rituals, making the experience even more profound. Tips for Visitors Dress respectfully, covering shoulders and knees, as it is a sacred site. Walk clockwise around the stupa as part of Buddhist tradition. Bring offerings such as flowers and incense if you wish to participate in rituals. Be mindful of the peaceful atmosphere – avoid loud conversations and respect the devotion of pilgrims. Overall Experience ⭐ 5/5 – Ruwanwelisaya is a must-visit landmark in Sri Lanka, not only for its religious significance but also for its architectural beauty and serene surroundings. Whether you seek spiritual fulfillment or a glimpse into Sri Lanka’s ancient history, this stupa is a truly remarkable destination.

As the oldest stupa in Sri Lanka, Ruwanwelisaya stands as a magnificent symbol of architectural greatness from ancient times. Also known as the Great Stupa, this incredible structure was constructed by the victorious King Dutugemunu in 140 BC. It was his grand vision to revive Buddhism in the country, and this stupa stands as a testament to his dedication and ambition. The compound of Ruwanwelisaya is adorned with a stunning parade of elephants carved around its base, adding to its majestic beauty. The design of this site was inspired by the teachings of the Buddha, with each element holding deep significance. The dome represents the vastness of Buddhist doctrine, the four facets symbolize the Four Noble Truths, the concentric rings signify the Noble Eightfold Middle Path, and the large crystal at the pinnacle represents the ultimate goal of enlightenment. Located near the Jaya Maha Bodhi Tree in Anuradhapura, Ruwanwelisaya is a sacred site that holds relics of the Buddha, attracting worshippers from all over the world. Standing at an impressive height of 388 feet with a base diameter of 90 meters and a circumference of 950 feet, this stupa is recognized as one of the tallest monuments globally. Ruwanwelisaya is one of the eight revered places in Anuradhapura believed to have been visited by Buddha during his three trips to Sri Lanka. As a place of worship, visitors are required to remove their shoes before entering the area, adding to the sacred atmosphere. While Ruwanwelisaya is often included in the sights of the 'Sacred City' Archaeological Park, entry to this magnificent site is free as it lies outside the paid area. Visitors can also explore nearby attractions such as the ruins of Lovamahapaya Brazen Palace and Sri Maha Bodhi, the primary Buddhist site in the region.

Ruwanweliseya, also known as the Ruwanwelisaya or Ruins of Anuradhapura, is a significant religious site located in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. It is one of the country's most revered and ancient stupas, holding great religious and historical importance. Ruwanweliseya is one of the oldest stupas in Sri Lanka, with a history dating back to the 2nd century BC. It stands as a testament to the rich cultural and religious heritage of the region. The stupa is an architectural marvel, with a large hemispherical dome and a spire at its center. The entire structure is adorned with intricate carvings and decorative elements, showcasing the skilled craftsmanship of ancient Sri Lankan builders. Ruwanweliseya is a sacred pilgrimage site for Buddhists. It enshrines relics believed to be associated with Lord Buddha, making it a place of deep spiritual significance for followers of Buddhism. Visitors often mention the serene and peaceful atmosphere surrounding the stupa. The site is well-maintained, and the lush greenery adds to the overall tranquility, providing a calm and reflective environment for visitors. Exploring Ruwanweliseya offers a glimpse into Sri Lanka's rich cultural and religious traditions. Observing religious ceremonies or interacting with local worshippers can enhance the cultural experience for visitors. The stupa's impressive architecture, particularly during sunrise or sunset, provides excellent photo opportunities. The Ruwanwelisaya is a stupa, a hemispherical structure containing relics, in Sri Lanka, considered sacred to many Buddhists all over the world.[1] It was built by King Dutugemunu[citation needed] c. 140 B.C., who became King of all Sri Lanka after a war in which the Chola King Ellalan, was defeated. It is also known as "Mahathupa", "Swarnamali Chaitya", "Suvarnamali Mahaceti" (in Pali) and "Rathnamali Dagaba". Ruwanweli Maha Seya රුවන්වැලිසෑය The Ruwanwelisaya Stupa Religion Affiliation Theravada Buddhism Location Country Sri Lanka Ruwanwelisaya is located in Sri LankaRuwanwelisaya Location in Sri Lanka Geographic coordinates 8°21′0″N 80°23′47″E Architecture Founder King Dutugamunu Completed circa 140 BC This is one of the "Solosmasthana" (the 16 places of veneration) and the "Atamasthana" (the 8 places of veneration in the ancient sacred city of Anuradhapura). The stupa is one of the world's tallest ancient monuments, standing at 103 m (338 ft) and with a circumference of 290 m (951 ft). The original stupa had been about 55 m (180 ft) in height and was renovated by many kings.The Kaunghmudaw Pagoda in Sagaing, Myanmar is modeled after this stupa. The stupa was a ruin in the 19th century. After fundraising efforts by a Sinhalese bhikkhu, it was renovated in the early 20th century.The Ruwanveli Seya Restoration Society was founded in 1902 and the final crowning of the stupa took place on 17 June 1940.

More precisely it costs 4600 rupees. A ticket is made of three stubs that need to be torn off every time you enter one of the three areas. There are some tuk tuk drivers who might ask you to give them your ticket so that they can show it to the surveillance staff in order to enter the area. The point is that there are some tuk tuk drivers who take their customers tickets just to show them what they want to show. They aim at ending their trip with the customers asap so that they can start a new trip with other tourists who will be sold the same tickets partly used by the previous tourists.To cut it short tuk tuk drivers resell those tickets to other tourists at a reduced price and take the money deriving from the sell. So be careful. I also want to give some quick information on how to arrive in Anuradhapura if you come from Dambulla. Dambulla is a small city. There is not bus station but of course there are bus stops. The one where you can catch the bus to Anuradhapura is on Kandy road (the main road) 200 meters after the clock tower on your left next to Bata shoe shop. The bus numbers to consider are 15 and 43. This huge white stupa is another place of active Buddhist worship, though less busy than Sri Maha Bodhi. Its construction is said to have begun over 2,000 years ago, but from its well-maintained look, much of it may be of more recent origin. It is characterised by a parade of elephants carved in relief all around the base of the stupa. As a place of worship, shoes have to be removed to enter the area. Ruwanwelisaya is usually listed as among the sights of “Sacred City/Ancient Ruins” park, but it lies outside the paid area, in other words, entry is free. From here it is a short walk southwards to the ruins of Lovamahapaya Brazen Palace (nothing much to see, free) and further south, to Sri Maha Bodhi, the chief Buddhist site in the area (also free). General info about places in the “Sacred City/Ancient Ruins” park: The sights are quite spread out such that while walking from one sight to the second may be possible, covering many more on foot is impractical. You’ll need a map and a bicycle or a tuktuk hired for the day. Also, there few toilets, and few places to buy drinking water. Be prepared.

Something to feel and understand.  It is the feeling of the heat of the paved slabs or rock steps under your feet and an appreciation and understanding forming of what worship is like for these people here.  It is the physical exertion on your body to reach the highest point.  It is the tranquility of the landscape that these sights are built around.  It is the bewilderment of the age of the relics and the size in which some have been made.  It is the sights of monkeys behaving like this is their home.  It is the noise of traditional music as an organ may be playing if you were to visit a Cathedral.  It is the gentle murmurs of worship coming from peoples prayers.  It is the shade of the tree whether it be regarded as holy or not.  It is the smell of incense and the sight of flowers given as a gift.  It is the welcoming smiles of the Sri Lankan people who are happy to include you here regardless of your religion. It is something you do and recommend you do when you are visiting another country.

There are gigantic stupas the size of Egyptian pyramids, which contain holy Buddhist relics and an incredible irrigation system that are both nearly 2000 years old. Also to be visited on the site is the Sri Maha Bohdi – apparently one of the world’s oldest and most revered trees. It is probably worth retaining the services of an official guide, such is the complexity of the history and scale of the site.  We attended on a Sunday which due to the site’s highly religious importance meant it was very crowded with pilgrims.  From a cultural point of view this was fascinating, but those interested in the history of the place might find a less busy, mid-week visit, more rewarding.  Whenever you choose, Anuradhapura is certainly worth seeing.

Dagoba or Stupa is a dome shaped shrine.  Ruwanweli Dagoba is said to contain relics of Buddha.  It is the second most venerated buddhist site (next to Sri Maha Bodhi) in the historic Anuradhapura. We went to see this colossal structure, marvelled for its architectural qualities, early in the morning and again late in the evening.  We walked all around the dome observing throngs of devouts offering flowers as well as people in meditation and religious worship. The Dagoba is said to have been built around 140 b.c. by king Dutugemunu. The original stupa had been about 55 metres in height and had been expanded and renovated by many kings thereafter. Currently it stands at 107 metres in height and 93 metres in diameter. According to history, King Dutugamunu, who initiated the construction, did not live to see the completion of this massive Dagoba. His brother took over the construction when the king fell ill. The king wanted to see the Daboba before his death.  The upper incomplete portion was completed using bamboo, and covered with white cloth.  The king had been carried on his deathbed to show the "completed" dagoba. You see the statues of King Dutugamunu and his mother Vihara Maha Devi around the Dagoba. Wonderful place to visit if you are interested in architecture and history.  An essential site of veneration for Buddhists! Note:  Foreigners need to purchase a ticket (about 16 usd) that covers visits to all historic Anuradhapura locations.  Visitors are required to be appropriately dressed and no shoes to be worn within the premises.  There was no objection to taking photographs.

RUWANWELISAYA DAGOBAH Ruwanwelisaya is an awe inspiring Dagobah of magnificent architectural style, built during the reign of King Dutugemunu (140 BC). The Dagobah has circumference of 950 feet and height of 338 feet. In 19th century AD, this Dagobah was nothing more than ruins of a magnificent structure. In 20th century, it was renovated and restored with local donations and assistance from UNESCO. It is now a World Heritage Site. A Dagobah is a sacred place of veneration. Generally it is a shrine like domed structure in which are placed relics related to Buddha, Buddhism or remains of Buddhist monks and nuns. The place is also used for meditation and worship. It is also called Stupa, Pagoda or Chedi.

If you visit Sri Lanka then you must come to this area and visit the Dagoba This magnificent white dagoba is guarded by a wall with a frieze of hundreds of elephants standing shoulder to shoulder. A limestone statue south of the great dagoba is popularly thought to be of Dutugemunu. There is a serenity to this area a respect that every person visiting this place should and must adhere too. This was our first stop in Sri Lanka and I wish I had known more history before we saw the sites.  The current remains of this ancient kingdom are spread out, making it hard to appreciate the whole of the kingdom.  Anaradhapura was coincident with the Roman empire and traded with the Romans as well as more distant lands.  I would strongly recommend a little homework or using a guide who can explain the history of Anaradhapura and Polonnaruwa before seeing the actual archeology sites.  Polonnaruwa is more intact but Anaradhapura is a temple/stupa/cave/tree here and there.  It is, in fact, the oldest set of Buddhist temples in the world and the best preserved ancient stupas.  Once I read more about it, I realized what a privilege it was to have seen these pivotal structures. Anything in the range of 1300 to 1800 LKR is the auto hire charges. It will take 4 hours to see complete sightseeing of beautiful ancient ruins in Anuradhapura. Ruwanwelisaya Dagoba (Stoopa) will be 1 of the spots out of 10 from your Anuradhpura sightseeing tour. This is the most sacred Stoopa in Srilanka. That’s why after Sri Maha Bodhi temple, Ruwanvelisya is the place where you will find people in huge numbers in Anuradhpura. The wall compound of this stoopa is decorated with elephant figures on all the sides. A must place to visit in Anuradhpura. See the attached photos of Ruwanvelisaya Dagoba.

This place is definitely worth a visit. The stupa is one of the holiest in Sri Lanka. It’s a wonderful, well maintained and beautiful place to visit. You can feel the spirituality while you’re visiting the site.

The dagoba being one of several nestled amidst the Anuradhapura sacred sites (8 in total), it may not be the most impressive (despite the elephants lining up along its base) but it is located near the sacred Bo Tree and can be explored together with the sights of this historic monastery. The place is vast and heat absorbing socks are a must! The dagoba is renovated regularly by pilgrims, painting and repairing the works. The number of outbuildings and secondary sites here draws a great many pilgrims from all parts of Sri Lanka. Access is easy, no steps to climb and parking nearby (reducing the barefoot experience..).

An enormous monument and a masterclass in ancient Sri Lankan Engineering. This monument is said to hold the largest amount of Buddha's mortal relics. This is a must see site for any tourist to Sri Lanka. Must be dressed conservatively where most of the body is covered to enter this spiritual site. Shoes and hats must be removed before entering. This is part of an enormous temple / university / hospital complex that was known as the Maha Vihara. Tourists will marvel at the feats of ancient engineering by viewing the scattering of ancient foundations and granite carvings. Simply magnificent!
